newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African Airways says go-slow costs 40 mln rand.
newsitem.headline: S.African Airways says go-slow costs 40 mln rand.

text.p: South African Airways (SAA) said on Wednesday a week-long go-slow by technicians and engineers had cost it about 40 million rand so far.
"The loss has been very substantial," spokeswoman Zelda Schuulabach said.

"At present we're looking at losses in the region of 40 million rand. That includes an estimated loss of market share over the next three months because we realise these delays, especially on our international flights, will have a negative effect and passengers will probably choose to fly with competitors."

Many domestic and international SAA flights have been cancelled or delayed because of the work-to-rule by the South African Aviation Engineering and Allied Union (SAAEAU) which began on Wednesday last week.
SAA has asked union members to sign undertakings that they will return to normal working or face being locked out.

Schuulabach said several flights serving Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban had been combined on Wednesday. "We have reduced our frequencies but we have increased our capacities (by using larger aircraft)," she said.
She advised people who had no pressing need to travel to postpone their journeys until the union action was over.
SAAEAU has declared a dispute with SAA for its refusal to offer a 25 percent wage rise. Management is offering a 10 percent increase plus a 20 percent productivity bonus.
